meta.title: About the project
meta.description: Overview of the Bachelor's thesis by Ram√≥n de Smit: Do You Trust Me? 3D Avatars for the trustworthy provision of study information.

hero.title: Do You Trust Me? 3D Avatars for the trustworthy provision of study information.
hero.author: Author

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.body: The thesis investigates to what extent an interactive 3D-AI avatar can increase trust and comprehensibility in the provision of study information (Master's program Computer Science, University of Bremen). A web-based system was developed that combines real-time speech input, speech synthesis, 3D animation (blendshaping), and context-adaptive rendering. In the automated evaluation, two interaction modes are compared primarily in terms of trust: Avatar interface vs. text interface.

short.title: Project at a glance
short.domain: Domain: Study information for the Computer Science Master's program at the University of Bremen
short.modes: Interaction modes: 3D avatar (speech dialogue, facial expressions, gestures) and text chat
short.goals: Goals: Build trust, open-source solution, locally runnable & free to use
short.privacy: Privacy: Anonymous, no storage of sensitive personal data

research.title: Research questions
research.q1: How does interaction with a humanized, multimodal 3D-AI tutor influence students‚Äô trust when seeking study information at the University of Bremen?
research.q2: Does the avatar improve the perceived comprehensibility and usefulness of the information?
research.q3: What is the effect of the agent‚Äôs emotional reactivity (e.g. changes in facial expressions or body animations in response to observations)?
research.q4: Does the Uncanny Valley effect occur, and do the chosen measures counteract it?
research.q5: How does the design of modalities (voice, expressions, visual design, UI) affect social presence?

method.title: Methodology
method.body: Within-subjects design with balanced order (AB/BA). The avatar and text interface modes are each evaluated using standardized metrics (NASA-TLX) and custom questions. Metrics include duration, interaction steps, and self-assessments of trust and clarity.

block.title: The General Attitudes towards Artificial Intelligence Scale (GAAIS)

instructions.title: Instruction:
instructions.body: We are interested in your attitudes towards Artificial Intelligence. By Artificial Intelligence we mean algorithms running on computers that can perform tasks that would usually require human intelligence. These can be computers, robots or other hardware devices, possibly augmented with sensors or cameras. Please complete the following scale, indicating your response to each item. There are no right or wrong answers. We are interested in your personal views.

response.body: (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neutral, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
